questionOriginal: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. These symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus:

  • Fever

  • Cough

  • Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

  • Chills

  • Repeated shaking with chills

  • Muscle pain

  • Sore throat

  • New loss of taste or smell

You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.

Call your health care professional if you develop symptoms and ask if a test can be considered. Learn more about COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, at this time, there is no evidence that animals play a large role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19, and no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets. Based on the limited information available at this time, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is considered to be low. A small number of pets have been reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, mostly after contact with people with COVID-19.

Pets have other types of coronaviruses that can make them sick, like canine and feline coronaviruses. These other coronaviruses cannot infect people and are not related to the current COVID-19 pandemic.

However, since animals can spread other diseases to people, itâs always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands and maintaining good hygiene. Find more information on staying safe and healthy around animals including pets from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 5, the USDA confirmed the first case of a tiger being infected with COVID-19. The tiger is at a zoo in New York.

On April 22, the CDC announced the first confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection in two pet cats. These are the first pets in the U.S. to test positive. The cats live in two separate areas of New York State. Find out more from the CDCâs press release Confirmation of COVID-19 in Two Pet Cats in New York.

The CDC recommends the following:

  • Do not let pets interact with people or other animals outside the household.

  • Keep cats indoors when possible to prevent them from interacting with other animals or people.

  • Walk dogs on a leash, keeping at least 6 feet from other people and animals.

  • Avoid dog parks or public places where large numbers of people and dogs may gather.

At this time, routine testing of animals for COVID-19 is not recommended. Talk to your veterinarian about the best ways to care for your pet.

Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
questionText: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are sick with COVID-19 (either suspected or confirmed by a test), avoid contact with your pets and other animals, just like you would around other people.

  • When possible, have another member of your household care for your pets while you are sick.

  • Avoid contact with your pet, including petting, snuggling, being kissed or licked, and sharing food or bedding.

  • If you must care for your pet or be around animals while you are sick, wear a cloth face mask or covering and wash your hands before and after you interact with them.

Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.

Find more information on preparing for your pet from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Do family members of people who traveled internationally or by cruise ship need to stay at home?
questionText: Do family members of people who traveled internationally or by cruise ship need to stay at home?
answerOriginal:
If your family member has traveled internationally to any country or traveled by cruise ship or river cruise voyage, they should quarantine for 14 days, and the other household members should do self-observation for 14 days. Learn more on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Find more information from the CDC about returning from international travel and returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages.

Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

questionOriginal: I traveled through an international airport. Do I need to notify the Health Department?
questionText: I traveled through an international airport. Do I need to notify the Health Department?
answerOriginal:
Travelers with international layovers returning to Vermont need to follow the same monitoring guidelines as if they are a returning traveler from that country. If you have a layover in China or Iran, you should:

  1. Call your health care provider and

  2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240

Read the CDCâs guidance on returning from international travel.

questionOriginal: Where is it safe to travel internationally? Is it safe to go on a cruise ship or river cruise?
questionText: Where is it safe to travel internationally? Is it safe to go on a cruise ship or river cruise?
answerOriginal:
The Department of State has issued a Global Level 4 Health Advisory, and the CDC recommends that travelers avoid all nonessential international travel.

The CDC also recommends that no one travel on cruise ships, including river cruises, worldwide. Thatâs because the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is high.

Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

You can also check the CDC's FAQs for Travelers.

questionOriginal: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order ban travel to neighboring states for work or court-ordered parental visitation?
questionText: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order ban travel to neighboring states for work or court-ordered parental visitation?
answerOriginal:
No. If you are in an essential industry in a neighboring state, or if you need to drop off or pick up children from court-ordered parental visits, for example, that is considered essential travel.

However, if you come in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19, you should self-quarantine for 14 days, just as you would if the contact occurred in Vermont.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about what to do if youâre a close contact of someone with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
questionText: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answerOriginal:
Cases of COVID-19 have been reported in all states, and some areas are experiencing community spread of the disease. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.

The CDC recommends you stay home as much as possible, especially if your trip is not essential, and practice social distancing especially if you are at higher risk of severe illness. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick.

In Vermont, people from other states and countries are still being asked not to visit. If they do, they are required to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after arriving in Vermont before engaging in any activities, such as grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
questionText: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answerOriginal:
Visitors from other states, and countries, are still being asked not to come to Vermont. If they do, they are required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone who leaves Vermont for more than one day for travel that is not âessential" is required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Essential travel is defined as travel required for personal safety; food, beverage or medicine; medical care; care of others; and to perform work, services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security. Read Addendum 6 for more details.

For those who are in a 14-day quarantine, you may need to rely on neighbors, friends or family living outside of the household to deliver groceries to your home. Check your local grocery store to see if there is an option for home delivery or look for online sources for home delivery. Groceries should always be left at your door. Wash your hands before and after if a signature for receipt is required.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

Read Addendum 7 and Addendum 13 for more information about travel into Vermont.

questionOriginal: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
questionText: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answerOriginal:
If you are a second or seasonal homeowner (including an RV located in Vermont), you are encouraged to stay in your primary home unless you donât have other options. However, the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order does not prevent people from going to their seasonal home or RV.

Any individual returning to, or traveling to, Vermont from another state or country for non-essential reasons is required to quarantine at home for 14 days upon their return and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks, and must comply with all of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

questionOriginal: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
questionText: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
answerOriginal:
Families can call Help Me Grow-VT at 2-1-1 ext. 6 to be directed to services in their area that may be able to assist with formula, diapers, or other necessities.

Vermont WIC provides healthy foods, nutrition education, and breastfeeding support to pregnant and postpartum Vermonters and caregivers of infants and children under 5. Vermont WIC is open and invites new and returning families to join. If your family financial circumstances have changed due to a job loss or reduced hours, you could be eligible for WIC.

WIC has made a few changes to keep families and staff safe during the COVID-19 pandemic. All appointments are being done by phone and breastfeeding classes are offered online.

Apply for WIC online or text VTWIC to 855-11. You can also connect with WIC in your area.

Food banks and food shelves may be resources for families not eligible for WIC. Find more information on food access from Hunger Free Vermont.

Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
questionText: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself. According to the FDA, in the early days of an infection when the bodyâs immune response is still building, antibodies may not be detected. This limits the testâs effectiveness for diagnosing COVID-19 and why it should not be used as the sole basis to diagnose COVID-19.

With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available are not accurate or reliable enough. Based on these findings, they caution against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals. For example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

We will continue to use public health best practice â considering clinical data, exposure history, and what is happening at the community-level â to make decisions on when to reopen businesses and when to return to work. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.

There is also a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.

The Health Department shares information for towns as a number range. This is to protect the privacy of people who have tested positive for COVID-19. If some information is made public (for example, gender, age, race, health condition, travel history), then a person could be identified, especially if the population of a town is small. This follows both federal and Vermont laws.

The COVID-19 virus is spreading throughout Vermont, and many people may have it and can spread it for up to two days before they show symptoms. It is safe to assume that the virus is in your town or community, and you should take steps to protect yourself and others.

A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
questionText: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
answerOriginal:
There is programming for PreK through 12th grade that is aligned to nationalâand customized to Vermontâstandards. The programming available from a partnership with the Agency of Education and Vermont PBS includes interactive lessons and paired suggested activities for educators, students and families. There are also resources available that allow teachers and caregivers to access at-home curriculum that includes activities, assignments and learning objectives.

The programming will be available for the rest of the school year. It is available on all cable systems and for free over the air through a digital antenna without the need for cable subscription or broadband internet access.

questionOriginal: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
questionText: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.

Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.

We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
questionText: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

  • Socialize with household members or one other trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions.

  • Wash hands often using soap and water or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Avoid people who are sick (coughing and sneezing).

  • Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).

  • Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.

questionOriginal: How should we practice social distancing with children?
questionText: How should we practice social distancing with children?
answerOriginal:
While Vermont schools are closed, itâs important for our whole community to re-think how we maintain social connections while also slowing the spread of disease.

Most people who get sick from COVID-19 â including children â will experience mild symptoms and recover, but staying at home, and practicing social distancing when you must go out, will help us limit the virusâs spread to our vulnerable populations. Social distancing means keeping about 6 feet away from others and avoiding places where you may be close to other people.

Spend time outdoors. As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Learn how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family who you are not gathering with. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.

Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: I split custody with my children. Can we still continue to bring our children from one home to another, or do we need to follow the 14-day self-quarantine for each visit?
questionText: I split custody with my children. Can we still continue to bring our children from one home to another, or do we need to follow the 14-day self-quarantine for each visit?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department encourages parents to follow State and CDC guidelines for travel and social distancing. Be sure to consider the health of each household, including if anyone in the homes has current symptoms of COVID-19 or has an underlying medical condition before moving a child between them. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

If one of the parents has concerns and does not want to move children between households, we encourage parents to consult with their childâs pediatrician to discuss any possible health risks to the child.
answerText:
The Health Department encourages parents to follow State and CDC guidelines for travel and social distancing. Be sure to consider the health of each household, including if anyone in the homes has current symptoms of COVID-19 or has an underlying medical condition before moving a child between them. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
If one of the parents has concerns and does not want to move children between households, we encourage parents to consult with their childâs pediatrician to discuss any possible health risks to the child.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I have to work and need child care?
questionText: What do I do if I have to work and need child care?
answerOriginal:
Child care has been available for those who have been deemed essential to the COVID-19 response. These are workers in critical businesses who are working out of the home and do not have other options are eligible for child care. Find more information and fill out an online form for child care assistance. There are options for child care for children up to grade 8. You can also call 2-1-1 ext. 6.

Starting June 1, child care providers can decide to reopen if they follow health and safety precautions. Some may choose not to reopen or are unable to do so. Find more information on child care from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

questionOriginal: Is there a rapid (fast) test for COVID-19?
questionText: Is there a rapid (fast) test for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Vermont will soon have a has a limited supply of rapid COVID-19 test machines and supplies. These tests take about 15 minutes for results. Currently, the Health Department is confirming the accuracy of these new tests to detect COVID-19 before they are used. Once they are validated, the Health Department will determine the best locations for these testing machines based on a number of factors. Potential locations could include hospitals, small facilities experiencing a COVID-19 outbreak, and new testing sites.

Read the Health Departmentâs COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses.

questionOriginal: Are hotels, motels and other lodging facilities closed?
questionText: Are hotels, motels and other lodging facilities closed?
answerOriginal:
Yes. All lodging facilities â which includes hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities and RV parks â are closed, unless they are helping with the Stateâs COVID-19 response.

New reservations for stays and events occurring on June 15 or later can be made. This date may be changed or extended.

All reservations between May 15 and May 22 need to be canceled. All reservations from out-of-state guests who cannot first meet the mandatory 14-day quarantine requirements must also be canceled through June 15. This date may be changed or extended.

Find up-to-date information on lodging and accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

questionOriginal: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
questionText: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answerOriginal:
As of March 30, Governor Scott ordered all lodging facilities to close, except for exemptions when supporting the stateâs COVID-19 response. Lodging facilities include hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities and RV parks.

Governor Scott announced on April 10 that lodging operators may accept new reservations for stays and events occurring on June 15 or later. However, if the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order is extended, they will need to rebook.

All reservations between May 15 and May 22 need to be canceled. All reservations from out-of-state guests who cannot first meet the mandatory 14-day quarantine requirements must also be canceled through June 15. This date may be changed or extended.

Find up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

Businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements that requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses.

The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

questionOriginal: What should child care programs and schools in Vermont do?
questionText: What should child care programs and schools in Vermont do?
answerOriginal:
Schools for PreK-12 students remain dismissed for in-person instruction for the rest of the 2019-2020 school year. Schools are required to have continuity of learning plans for remote learning implemented.

On May 8, education officials provided guidance on end-of-the-year gatherings. Large gatherings will not be permitted through the end of the school year, and events should be virtual.

Starting June 1, child care providers can decide to reopen if they follow health and safety precautions. Some may choose not to reopen or are unable to do so. Find guidance on child care from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development as it becomes available.

Child care programs remain open for Essential Persons, which are defined as including:

  • staff and providers of child care and education services (including custodial and kitchen staff and other support staff) for children of other Essential Persons

  • providers of healthcare

  • criminal justice personnel

  • public health employees

  • firefighters

  • Vermont National Guard personnel called to duty for this response

  • other first responders

  • state employees determined to be essential for response to this crisis under the State Emergency Operations Center.

Read the Health Guidance for Childcare Programs, Summer Programs and Afterschool Programs that are or will open during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Find more information for schools and child care programs.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I have a dental emergency?
questionText: What should I do if I have a dental emergency?
answerOriginal:
There are some cases where you may need to see a dentist. Some in-person treatment options may be limited because some dental treatments produce aerosol, which raises the risk of spreading COVID-19. And in some cases, complete care may not be safe to provide during the pandemic.

If you are experiencing one of the following symptoms or situations, then you should contact your regular dentist:

  • Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
  • Painful swelling in or around your mouth
  • Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
  • Gum infection with pain or swelling
  • Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
  • Broken or knocked out tooth
  • Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
  • Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
  • Biopsy of abnormal tissue

You can contact your regular dentist by:

  • Phone â calling or texting
  • Video chats through FaceTime, Skype, Facebook Messenger or Google Hangouts

If you donât have a regular dentist, call 211, and they can assist you in finding one.

The dentist will ask you if you have a fever (take a current temperature reading), dry cough, or trouble breathing. They will be able to give you advice to alleviate pain, swelling or other urgent issue.

For more information on what is a dental emergency, please check the American Dental Associationâs patient guide.
answerText:
There are some cases where you may need to see a dentist. Some in-person treatment options may be limited because some dental treatments produce aerosol, which raises the risk of spreading COVID-19. And in some cases, complete care may not be safe to provide during the pandemic.
If you are experiencing one of the following symptoms or situations, then you should contact your regular dentist:

Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
Painful swelling in or around your mouth
Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
Gum infection with pain or swelling
Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
Broken or knocked out tooth
Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
Biopsy of abnormal tissue

You can contact your regular dentist by:

Phone â calling or texting
Video chats through FaceTime, Skype, Facebook Messenger or Google Hangouts

If you donât have a regular dentist, call 211, and they can assist you in finding one.
The dentist will ask you if you have a fever (take a current temperature reading), dry cough, or trouble breathing. They will be able to give you advice to alleviate pain, swelling or other urgent issue.
For more information on what is a dental emergency, please check the American Dental Associationâs patient guide.

questionOriginal: Is there food available if I need it?
questionText: Is there food available if I need it?
answerOriginal:
People in need can receive a free, seven-day supply of ready-to-eat meals for each member of their household. The Vermont Foodbank and Vermont National Guard will give out free food throughout the month of May.

People who are sick, have been asked to quarantine, or donât have transportation can send a friend or relative to pick up meals for them. Those picking up food can come to the location nearest to them, open their trunk, and the food will be loaded by members of the Vermont National Guard.

Find more details, dates and locations for meal distribution for those in need.

Vermont food shelves are also able to meet the demand of clients and Vermont grocery stores are not experiencing shortages of most food items.

Visit the Vermont Foodbank for more details on food resources during COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
questionText: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.

802Quits is the Vermont tobacco quit resource. You can get help to quit by phone or online.

By phone, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for 1:1 coaching, available 24/7, with email and text support.

Online: 802Quits.org

By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home right now.

questionOriginal: What should health care workers do?
questionText: What should health care workers do?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department now has a dedicated webpage for health care workers - healthvermont.gov/covid19-providers. It includes current guidance, health alerts, and resources for protecting patients and health care workers in different settings.

Report all suspected cases of COVID-19 immediately to the Vermont Department of Health Infectious Disease Epidemiology by calling 802-863-7240 (24/7).

If you suspect that a patient with a fever or respiratory illness has COVID-19:

  • Give the patient a surgical mask.

  • Notify facility infection control personnel immediately.

  • Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.

  • Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room

Give the patient a surgical mask.

Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.


Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room

questionOriginal: What is contact tracing?
questionText: What is contact tracing?
answerOriginal:
Contact tracing is a strategy used to determine the source of an infection and how it is spreading. Finding people who are close contacts to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, and therefore at higher risk of becoming infected themselves, can help prevent further spread of the virus.

A team of callers tries to reach anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. They ask the patient questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than six feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) Those contacts might include family members, co-workers or health care providers. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

The team then gets in touch with those contacts and provides health guidance on what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19. A close contact is asked to stay home for 14 days and watch for symptoms.

While we have been successful in contact tracing, we will continue to add resources and personnel needed to address any increase in the number of people who test positive, which we expect to happen with more testing. This includes the use of technology to help in these efforts. We will be using an app called SARA Alert, a secure monitoring and reporting system for public health that is being used in other states. This system will allow us to offer people who have tested positive for COVID-19, and their close contacts, to enroll in a text-based system to help us keep in touch and monitor their symptoms.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
answerOriginal:
The Heath Department is contacting all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.

If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.

questionOriginal: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
questionText: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 27, a dental health care referral network for emergency dental procedures was set up. Read the April 27 Health Alert.

On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended his order of dental health care professionals practicing in Vermont to suspend all elective dental care until May 15, 2020. This order applies to both children and adult patients. Read Addendum 9 to the Executive Order for more information.

Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.

Read the March 23 Health Alert as it pertains to emergency and elective dental care in light of COVID-19, the rationale for this action, including definitions of what constitutes a dental emergency and conditions requiring urgent care.

Find more information for health care professionals.

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing?
answerOriginal:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.

The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.

questionOriginal: Are bars and restaurants open?
questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerOriginal:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.

Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.

Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

questionOriginal: What is considered an essential service or function?
questionText: What is considered an essential service or function?
answerOriginal:
Businesses and entities providing services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security can remain open and do not need to suspend in-person operations. However, they must follow new mandatory health and safety requirements, such as wearing cloth face masks or coverings, social distancing, hygiene and cleaning requirements. Essential state and local government services and functions remain open. Find the list of essential services or functions.

For more information, read the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) Stay Home, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses and COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses.
answerText:
Businesses and entities providing services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security can remain open and do not need to suspend in-person operations. However, they must follow new mandatory health and safety requirements, such as wearing cloth face masks or coverings, social distancing, hygiene and cleaning requirements. Essential state and local government services and functions remain open. Find the list of essential services or functions.
For more information, read the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) Stay Home, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses and COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses.

questionOriginal: Where do the test samples get processed?
questionText: Where do the test samples get processed?
answerOriginal:
As of March 20, 2020, health care providers submit samples to the University of Vermont Medical Center Laboratory (UVMMC) for prioritization. Samples from higher risk populations will be tested at the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory. Lower priority tests are done at commercial labs.

The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

questionOriginal: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
questionText: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
answerOriginal:
In Vermont, additional measures are being taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities. This includes nursing homes, corrections facilities, residential homes for people with disabilities, residential treatment centers, assisted living facilities, state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters. In the event of a COVID-19 positive staff or resident, universal testing of all staff and residents is offered at these facilities. Staff and residents may decline testing, and facilities may decline universal testing.

Additionally, when a person tests positive at a skilled nursing facility, sequential testing is offered to those who tested negative during the universal testing.

questionOriginal: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for a referral. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for a referral to a test site. If you are having a medical emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to the hospital.

Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.

Find out what to do if you are sick from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test results.

Pop-up Testing Sites

Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. This includes people who work in Vermont, second homeowners, and college students. Registration for testing is required. For people who do not have internet access and want to register at a pop-up site, they can call 2-1-1 for help with registration.

Register for a pop-up testing site.

The test is a nasopharyngeal swab, or NP swab, where a health care professional uses a swab to collect a sample from the back of the nose and throat. This test will tell you if you have a current infection. It is not a serology/antibody test, which means it will not tell you if you were infected in the past.

The following groups are encouraged to get tested at pop-up sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you have been in close contact with a person who tested positive for COVID-19, monitor yourself for symptoms. This includes checking your temperature every day, watching for symptoms and staying home.

If you develop symptoms of COVID-19 and are a close contact of someone who tested positive, you should:

  1. Call your health care provider and

  2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

If you do not develop symptoms, you do not need to call the Health Department.

Read what to do if you're a close contact of someone with COVID-19.

Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I'm a close contact of someone who is waiting for their test results?
questionText: What do I do if I'm a close contact of someone who is waiting for their test results?
answerOriginal:
People can be contagious for up to 48 hours before showing symptoms, so you should quarantine for 48 hours or until the test results come back.

If the test results come back positive (the person has COVID-19), then you should continue to quarantine for 14 days.

If the test results come back negative (the person does not have COVID-19), then you should start self-observation.

Read the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart for details.

If the test results come back negative (the person does not have COVID-19), then you should start self-observation.

questionOriginal: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
questionText: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
answerOriginal:
There is no identifiable increased risk to someone who has been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring and is NOT sick (experiencing symptoms).

People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic (the sickest). It might be possible to spread the virus before people show symptoms â there have been reports of this happening â but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

questionOriginal: Should I wear a cloth face mask or covering when I go out in public?
questionText: Should I wear a cloth face mask or covering when I go out in public?
answerOriginal:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

As part of Governor Scottâs Work Smart & Stay Safe - Restart VT: Phase 3, people are required to wear cloth face masks or coverings over their nose and mouth when using public transportationâincluding buses, trains and ride services, and in mass transportation stations or terminals, including airports. Additionally, businesses and non-profit and government organizations may require customers or clients to wear cloth face masks or coverings.

The advice to wear cloth face masks or coverings is based on data about how COVID-19 can spread before a person has any symptoms. Because people may have COVID-19 but no symptoms, wearing cloth face masks or coverings may help keep people from spreading the virus.

We all still need to stay at least 6 feet away from people, even when wearing cloth face masks or coverings, practice good hand hygiene and follow the stateâs Stay Home, Stay Safe guidance.

The cloth face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:

  • Wash your hands before putting it on.

  • Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.

  • Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.

  • Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.

  • Keep it on until you get home.

  • Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.

  • Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.

Some people should never wear a cloth face mask or covering, including:

  • Children under the age of 2

  • Anyone who has trouble breathing, or is unconscious

  • Anyone who is unable to remove it without assistance

Medical-grade mask supplies are needed for our health care workers and first responders. Please use cloth face masks or coverings for your yourself and loved ones.

If you feel sick, stay home to rest and avoid going out into public places. If you are sick and plan to see a doctor, you should call the office before your visit. Your doctor can provide guidance on how to avoid spreading illness, such as what steps to take while traveling to their facility and upon arrival.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
questionText: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answerOriginal:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

Wearing a homemade cloth face mask or covering can offer some protection to others. This is because people may be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for up to two days (48 hours). The cloth face mask or covering can contain respiratory droplets and prevent them from spreading to others.

While health care workers may be able to use homemade cloth face masks or coverings as a last resort, medical-grade masks are considered personal protective equipment. These should be reserved for health care workers.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
questionText: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes. For example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.

questionOriginal: What does close contact mean?
questionText: What does close contact mean?
answerOriginal:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.

A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.

Examples of close contacts:

  • You live in the same home.

  • You are intimate partners.

  • You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.

  • You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

  • You were their cashier at the grocery store.

  • You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.

  • You were in front of the person in line at the store.

  • You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.

Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
questionText: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?

The Department of Public Safety has put together a list of businesses with available cloth face masks or coverings. Please check the list of where to buy cloth face coverings. Many Vermonters can also use homemade cloth face masks or coverings to offer some protection to others.

You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.

questionOriginal: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
questionText: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answerOriginal:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.

Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and avoid touching your face. Washing or wiping down your reusable bags with a disinfectant continues to be a best practice for preventing bacterial illnesses, such as E.coli, from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
questionText: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answerOriginal:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. However, there is concern about being able to keep at least 6 feet away from other shoppers and to reduce your risk of getting sick while getting groceries.

The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.

Anyone who is sick or thinks they might be sick should stay home. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.

When you leave the store, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

questionOriginal: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
questionText: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
CDC recommends the following for hand hygiene: Household members should clean hands often, including immediately after removing gloves and after contact with someone who is ill, by washing hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available and hands are not visibly dirty, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. However, if hands are visibly dirty, always wash hands with soap and water.

Hand Sanitizer Recipe (based on recipe from the World Health Organization):

  • 1 cup (250 mL) isopropyl alcohol (91%)

  • 1 teaspoon (5 mL) glycerol (or other moisturizer such as aloe vera gel, warm honey or olive oil)

  • 2 Tablespoons (33 mL) water

Add the ingredients in the order listed above to a clean container, mixing with a spoon. If using honey, stir until the honey is completely dissolved. Keep this mixture out of the reach of children. The final concentration of isopropyl alcohol in this mixture is 75%, so keep it away from flames.

questionOriginal: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
questionText: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
answerOriginal:
Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfecting your home guidance.

Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:

  • Follow the directions on the label

  • Donât mix chemicals

  • Wear protective gear (such as gloves)

  • Use them in a well-ventilated area

  • Store them out of reach of children

If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.

questionOriginal: How can I prepare at home?
questionText: How can I prepare at home?
answerOriginal:
• Plan ways to care for those in your home who might be at greater risk for serious complications, like older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions. Make sure those who need regular medicine, medical supplies and equipment have what they need.

  • Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate sick household members from those who are healthy. Identify a separate bathroom for the sick person to use, if possible. Plan to clean these rooms, as needed, when someone is sick.

  • Make sure you have enough groceries and other supplies for 14 days in case you get sick and need to quarantine. Stock up on only what you will need for 14 days. Do not buy more than you will need so you can leave supplies for other people.

  • Get support from others. Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning. If your neighborhood has Front Porch Forum, consider joining to connect with neighbors, information and resources. Stay in touch by phone or email with family and friends, especially those who are 65 years and older, who have underlying medical conditions, or who live alone.

  • Take care of the emotional health of your household members. Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe.

  • Keep a daily list of other people you are in close contact with. As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

Read Preventing COVID-19: Tips for Large Households or Extended Families Living in the Same Space.

questionOriginal: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
questionText: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, some people might be at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19, including older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, lung disease or moderate to severe asthma, severe obesity, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, liver disease, or people who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment. People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility are also at high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.

In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, older adults and people with underlying medical conditions should take extra precautions including:

  • Continue your medications and do not change your treatment plan without talking to your health care provider.

  • Stay home as much as possible, leaving only for essential purposes, like going to the grocery store and pharmacy. Consider having groceries or medications delivered.

  • Have at least a 2-week supply of prescription and non-prescription medications.

  • Talk to your health care provider about whether your vaccinations are up to date.

  • Do not delay getting emergency care for your underlying medical condition because of COVID-19.

  • Call your health care provider if you have any concerns about your underlying medical conditions or if you get sick and think that you may have COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs full guidance on people who are at higher risk for serious illness from COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
questionText: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answerOriginal:
The best way to prevent yourself and others from getting sick with COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Everyone should:

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.

  • If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.

  • Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.

  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.

  • Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Stay home when you are sick.

  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.

questionOriginal: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
questionText: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answerOriginal:
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials, according to the CDC. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or an object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. However, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces daily are the best ways to help stop the spread of the COVID-19 virus in households and community settings.

Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfection for households guidance for more information.

questionOriginal: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.

There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
questionText: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answerOriginal:
COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning about how it makes people sick.

Cause

COVID-19: Caused by one virus, the novel 2019 coronavirus, now called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2.

Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.

Transmission

While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.

Antiviral Medications

COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.

Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.

Vaccine

COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.

Flu: A vaccine is available and effective to prevent some of the most dangerous types or to reduce the severity of the flu.

Find out more about deaths and infections from Johns Hopkins Medicine.

Transmission
While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.

questionOriginal: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
questionText: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answerOriginal: The immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood. Patients with another type of coronavirus, MERS-CoV (also known as MERS) are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover, but it is not yet known whether this is true for people sick from COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.

Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:

Isolate at home:

  • Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care

  • Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

  • Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.

  • Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.

Daily cleaning and washing:

  • Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.

  • Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.

Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.

questionOriginal: I tested positive for COVID-19 but I never had symptoms. When can I stop home isolation?
questionText: I tested positive for COVID-19 but I never had symptoms. When can I stop home isolation?
answerOriginal:
If you didnât have symptoms when you were tested, you may stop home isolation when:

  • at least 10 days have passed since the date of your first positive COVID-19 test and
  • you still have not had any symptoms

After stopping home isolation, continue to stay 6 feet away from others and wear a cloth face mask or covering whenever other people are present.

questionOriginal: What should I do if Iâm being monitored by the Health Department and then become sick?
questionText: What should I do if Iâm being monitored by the Health Department and then become sick?
answerOriginal:
• If you have developed symptoms of COVID-19 AND

  • Have returned from China or Iran, or are a close contact of a person who tested positive for COVID-19, you should:

    1. Call your health care provider and
    2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

If you are being monitored because you have returned from an affected area other than China or Iran, or by cruise ship, you should call your health care provider if you become sick. It is not necessary to call the Health Department to report symptoms.

questionOriginal: What is monitoring?
questionText: What is monitoring?
answerOriginal:
Monitoring means someone who has returned from an affected area or cruise ship and does not have symptoms of COVID-19. They are advised by the Health Department to check their temperature every day, watch for symptoms, and quarantine for 14 days. Information that may identify someone under monitoring is not available to the public.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.

questionOriginal: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
questionText: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:

If you will not have a test to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you will be tested to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you no longer have a fever (without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • you received two negative tests in a row, 24 hours apart.

Your doctor will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

  • Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

  • Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.

  • These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.

  • Some recent studies have suggested that COVID-19 may be spread by people who are not showing symptoms.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

questionOriginal: Can I get the virus from food?
questionText: Can I get the virus from food?
answerOriginal:
Unlike foodborne gastrointestinal (GI) viruses that often make people sick from contaminated food, COVID-19 is a virus that causes respiratory illness. The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Currently, there is no evidence to show that COVID-19 is spread through food or food packaging.

It is important to always follow general food safety guidelines:

  • Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds before preparing or eating food.

  • Throughout the day, wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a package or container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Find shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the FDA and tips on how to handle and prepare food safely from the CDC.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

questionText: Can I get the virus from touching my mail or paper products?

questionOriginal: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
questionText: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answerOriginal:

Find more information from the CDC's Water and COVID-19 FAQs.

questionOriginal: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
questionText: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answerOriginal:
Anyone currently under quarantine who is not a health care worker or a correctional worker, and who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required.

This includes:

  • people returning to Vermont (for example, those who spend winter outside of Vermont, second homeowners and college students)

  • visitors coming into Vermont

  • close contacts of people who have tested positive

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 0 is the day you arrive in Vermont.

Health care workers and correctional workers must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

You can end your quarantine period only if:

  • You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period.

  • You are tested on Day 7 or later.

  • You remain in quarantine until the result comes back.

  • You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

However, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days and isolate at home immediately if symptoms develop.
